CatDescriptText: John Moranick, retired worker, West Homestead and Mrs. Theodore Stokes, housewife, 1130 Cresswell Street, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 28, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think race relations are improved, are worse, or about the same today as compared to pre-World War II years?" Mr. Moranick's answer reads: "They are very, very much improved....You now see colored where you never expected to see them..."  Mrs. Stokes answer reads: "They are improved, slightly.  There are better opportunities now in employment."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of John Moranick wearing herringbone coat, light colored fedora with dark band, patterned tie, and eyeglasses, holding box inscribed "P746 TURQ-W", standing in front of Bud Sanders flower shop, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Mrs. Theodore Stokes wearing eyeglasses, dark fur coat, earrings, and light colored gloves, standing in front of Bud Sanders flower shop, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
